unit_learning_outcomes.description: Develop effective communication projects in collaboration with others.
Apply skills in communicating through alternative media, and integrating communication through multiple media in specific contexts
Critically analyse more and less effective communication through the various media available
Demonstrate knowledge of the spectrum of communication media: spoken, written, electronic, contextual etc.
Apply communication expertise in editing students' own work and that of their peers
Evaluate changes in the way that we publish things and the effect they have on their audience

non_scheduled_learning_activities.description: Investigation into changes into different media/communicative contexts, to be brought to particular relevant weekly discussions (e.g. scope of e-books; museum signage)
Engagement in online discussion board based around weekly topic
Reading of online notes and additional readings related to weekly lectures.

assessments.description: Identification of features within different texts that mark them as formal/informal; print/online etc.

assessments.assessment_title: Sociology of the digital medium, online discussion
assessments.description: Students present arguments, based on provided stimulus articles, on the social effects of digital communication.
Students assess the range and content of documentation needed for a particular event, as part of a project group.

Students assess the content and functions of existing publications in different modes, and outline plans for another publication based on the same content, but using multimedia for a specific purpose.

school.value: Faculty of Medicine, Health and Human Sciences

data.description: This online unit aims to familiarise students with the myriad forms of communication, on- and off-line, so that they become critical receivers and effective producers, for any media they are working in.  It cultivates awareness of the language of public, social and private communication, and raises questions about the thresholds of publishing in the twenty-first century.  It examines the interplay between verbal communication and other visual, graphic and physical elements in specific contexts, such as exhibitions and in subtitling.  Some assignments are collaborative.  All are designed to develop individual skills in communication, to prepare for further training in professional editing in the Graduate Certificate in Editing and Electronic Publishing, and to substitute for the one-year's previous experience of editing which has hitherto been required.
data.title: Communication, Publishing and Editing
